description:
This place is very close from where I live, and I love it. The breakfast sandwiches are delicious! They are cheap and quick and totally worth it. The sausage egg and cheese bagel is where it is at. The coffee is pretty good. I mainly come here for convenience when I'm looking for something quick.

By the way, they have all this homemade food like chicken pasta salad and fruit yogurt parfaits, that I totally recommend. 

The girls behind the counter are all sweet and welcoming as well.
author: Nadia H.

description: Service - meh. Coffee - meh - over roasted like everyone else.  They don't know how to make a macchiato.  Bread pudding great, though.
author: Laura M.

description:
SoMa could definitely use another neighborhood cafe, but convenient hours would also be nice. I rarely walk by when this corner cafe is open because I'm usually doing my strolling in the evening after I do my routine at the gym (like letting the elliptical do the work for me) or the weekend when I'm getting coffee at The Market (since I can't afford anything else in there). Even though it's relatively new, the vibe here is a lot earthier than its geographically immediate brethren, Peet's and Coffee Cultures, where most of the hipsters congregate.

That may have to do with the pre-packaged picnic food they sell here rather than the high-end pastries of which they have just a few on the counter. I came in for just a $2.25 cup of their House Coffee (photo: http://bit.ly/2BRrtzX) and parked myself at one of their high-top tables. It was satisfying for a pick-me-up before heading home, and I noticed the motley customers coming in and out of the store looked like relatively normal people unlike the anorexically slender, nose-ringed youngsters who frequent the coffee stops across the street.

COFFEE - 4 stars...a fine cup of joe
AMBIANCE - 3.5 stars...pretty spacious
SERVICE - 3 stars...a bit indifferent but who cares
TOTAL - 4 stars...the hipsters go elsewhere, 'nuff said
author: Ed U.

description:
This Nicaraguan cafe looks interesting from the outside, but it's a bit warm, loud, and inconvenient to chill or get work done.  Between the spotty wi-fi connection for PCs and flying gnats, I'd rather go to Peet's across the street.  Their freshly squeezed orange juice is sweet and refreshing.  There is an assortment of coffee, snacks, and small bites, if you want to grab something to-go.

This place is within walking distance of public transit.  Parking can be tough on the street.  I had some hopes given the original name and authentic vibe coming in, but left without a desire to come back.
author: Jenny L.

description: I just recently started going here and I'm so glad I did! The matcha lattes are delicious, they offer dairy alternatives, and I'm a sucker for the lox bagel. Staff is also so warm and friendly!
author: Catherine M.

description: This place makes me happy and welcomed.  There are very similar coffee shops in the area with about the same price range, but the staff in this place are super nice and sweet which is why I always come here.   They are all bilingual, professional and warm.  The place is clean and inclusive.
author: Tiffany Q.

description:
Given the location across from Peet's the comparison is natural. As a fan of good coffee I was pleased to stumble upon this establishment after severe disappointment with their neighbors, 1) Coffee Cultures terrible product and 2) Peet's terrible service. 

Fortunately, Cumaica has consistently excelled in both realms and at a price point for a standard cup of black coffee that's competitive with the big chains. 

Give this place a try while the big boys unwisely rest on their laurels.
author: Jefferson S.

description: The environment is welcoming, warm. The staff was great. It's a place that makes you want to grad a cup of coffee, take a seat, and just appreciate the day. It is a great place to stop in for a good cup of coffee, a tasty bite, and good conversation. They also have plenty of tables and space if you need to get some work done. I will be back.
author: Norma O.

description:
Didn't even know this place existed, but I needed a caffeine fix on a Monday morning, and the next thing you know I was here.

Friendly (enough) servers, REALLY delicious coffee. I'd go back in a heartbeat if I were in this neighborhood and needed another fix.
author: Sean B.

description: These guys have some of the best espresso drinks. Had caramel macchiatto and mocha to go hoping for decent caffein boost. Turned out better tasting and quality caffein than Peets (not to mention Starbucks). Definitely recommend when craving for caffein in the area.
author: Brown D.

description: Still my favorite coffee place in SF! As if excellent coffee isn't enough reason to go here, it is a locally owned family business. The owner works very hard to ensure they are providing excellent coffee, excellent service and bettering the community. They provide jobs to immigrants and people with special needs. Every employee goes above and beyond to make your visit the best possible. This is the kind of business that makes SF a better place to be.
author: Nat C.

description:
I actually wanted just a cup of warm water and I ended up spending $6 for a cup of mocha and pudding :) happy about that tho !!!! Because warm rich coffee always wakes me up whenever I  feel tired  and sleepy :) so,  I think it worth it 

This is the first time ever I visited this place even tho I pass it every day!!!! Just because I was very hungry and I didn't really want to walk too far so... I decided to get some hot water there! They almost closed whn I was there but I suddenly wanted to try their pudding and if I got a pudding then I should get coffee as well so... I ordered a Mocha as always ;) and when I received my drink, OMG!!!! Rosemary the cashier who took my order made me a very very very skillful, beautiful and lovely coffee drawing :) she is soooo patient and value me as her late customer :))) (of course she also greeted me happily even I came in at the last minute) 

So 5 stars for her nice services :)))
author: Chiem E.

description: It is strange this place is not 5 star rating here - I love it: the food is healthy, staff is very pleasant and I have my coffee made quickly
author: Dmytro K.

description:
The staff were extremely friendly; the tuna sandwich fresh w a reasonable price, eggs well boiled, tea excellent, & trash receptacles plentiful as well as clean, a few tables weren't wiped down but overall cleanliness good, bathroom well maintained & stocked, & the atmosphere pleasant. 

I'd recommend this location.
author: Shaera H.

description:
Was given a gift card for here. Have tried to redeem it on 3 separate occasions . Each time the staff have refused to take it. Either they do not know how  redeem or they say the system is not working. At this stage it  seems like a scam. Take money for gift cards and then refuse to redeem them.

Confirmed today this business is running a scam. Was told to come back today and they would refund my money by Paola . Again the system was not working and she oozed attitude. Then the owner Roberto arrived and confirmed they sold gift cards and then shut down the system so people cannot redeem them . Basically pocketing the cash. I asked for a refund for my card and was told they could not find the card in there system. SCAM, SCAM...... Go to Pete's you get  great customer service and quality coffee.
author: Marie J.

description: Very bitter espresso. Underwhelming service. Ehhh burrito. Pretty nice atmosphere. Expected more, not coming back.
author: Sofia O.

description: I was excited since it's supposed to be an Artisan Cafe, but was not quite impressed. The coffee was average, the tables were sticky but the staff was nice and friendly.
author: Seerat S.

description:
I ordered iced coffee. It was not horrible but compared to other coffee shops in the city it was pretty mediocre. 

The main reason for my low rating is because I came here to work since its labeled an "internet cafe" and then after ordering and settling in to work I realized they only offer 30 minutes of internet access. 

Would rather they just didn't offer wifi if they are going to limit it to 30 minutes cause then I would have known to save this place for a time I wasn't looking to get work done.
author: Ashish M.

description: Bagel sandwiches, Burritos & espresso drinks are my favorite here. Modestly priced as well. Great addition to the market/van ness area coffee scene. I also like their location in the outer mission, but this is a great go to for food and an espresso. Large inside if you want to eat in- never overly busy which is great for civic center.
author: John O.

description:
Decent sized coffee shop, beverage and food items are very decent.

Started feeling hungry and thirsty as I passed by, so I came in to order a late snack. Ham & Cheese Sandwich plus a 16 oz Coffee go well together. Overall, positive experience! The staff members are friendly and service is efficient.

If you work nearby, this is a great place to come to on your break or before heading into the office.

It is always good to know that there is always a neighborhood coffee shop nearby when you are in need of a pastry and coffee.

There is Wi-Fi available so props to this amenity as always.

Here are their Business Hours:
Monday - Friday 5:30 am - 8:30 pm
Saturday - Sunday 5:30 am - 8:00 pm
author: Bennett W.

description:
Eh.  This place wreaked of loneliness with a side of pretension. I think that the location is a bit awkward not offering a lot of parking options and I'm sure the foot traffic is low.  The inside tries to be something it's not.  It's neither hip nor trendy with newness sprinkled through it's fixtures and fancy machines.

I wish the coffee was amazing to say something positive about this experience but with vagrancy lurking about the bathrooms remained locked so keys are needed.  The service was friendly enough but I think I might have waited a good three minutes at the counter while service hands stared blankly before being able to help. "...Hello?"

Thanks but no thanks Cumaica.  Hopefully you've developed some other followers.
author: Kevin J.

description:
My favorite place for my breakfast just near my work. 
I usually take an Americano ($2.5) here, delicious maybe a little bit too hot. I love their sandwiches, the best one is undoubtedly the turkey pesto ($6). They also have a Yoghurt Parfait, a bit pricy ($4,5) but delightful. The prices get more and more expensive (because of Twitter just near?) but way better than Starbucks. The staff is very friendly and there's a WiFi (password on your receipt) but unfortunately just for 30mins. :)

4 stars!
author: Lino M.

description:
Workers here are always pleasant and quick while the coffee is delicious with some tasty food surprises.

I typically get a latte or mocha and of those the iced white chocolate and caramel latte are solid choices.

What's most surprising is the multitude of food options. The black bean breakfast burritos are spectacular and most of the pastries are made fresh.
author: Allen J.

description: It was ok coffee. A cute spot. Nice place to hold meetings. But nothing special. The service isn't bad, and the ladies who work there are very nice. Good grab and go food. The coffee and so on is best in the morning time. It's a nice place to sit and I find myself coming back again and again.
author: Autumn H.

description:
The ambiance is really nice but thier staff is ok. They aren't mean but not friendly either. I'd rather go to a diff cofee shop if this wasn't the only thing near CIIS that's open late. 

They sell mostly pastries and bagels which is ok. I wished they sold gf products but I don't think they do. They are also very anal about the use of thier WiFi which is stupid. You get certain minutes and the code will be on your receipts. Is it always like that at cofee shops in SF? We just moved here so I'm not sure. 

I got thier turkey wrap which is better than what I expected. I also got an iced coffee which was ok. I wish that thier employees are friendlier. It would change how I think about the cafe itself.
author: Anna D.

description: Excellent service and the pasta salads are always a great breakfast for me. The green burrito doesn't sit well with my stomach. But I like this place.
author: Steph N.

description: I came here after searching "best wifi cafes to do work," and this looked pleasant and bright. Good enough food I suppose, But having only three outlets, requiring a purchase to use wifi, and having it time-limited on top of that? Won't come here to work again.
author: Gregory D.

description: This coffee shop is very near from my home. I like their bagels and i buy from them a lot of times. So today i thought give them a 5 star review to support my local business. Their prices are very affordable...
author: Zohaib S.

description:
Update 12/19/14

I've been coming here twice a day since I've started working in the new building right across the street. Continuous smiles by the beautiful baristas, tables are always clean, and the coffee is always strong. 

Now, I must add that these ladies can sure keep their cool. Some crackhead walked in yesterday at lunch and just started screaming and cursing! It was hilarious from my perspective because from my angle it looked like she was yelling at the pastries. Nonetheless, she walked out on her own and surprisingly, the baristas went straight back to work as if nothing happened. That's professionalism and I respect that.
author: Joey C.

description: I usually get their mozzarella/pesto panini but today I tried a bfast bagel and it was awesome! I had to get my usual for later so this time I will panini press it myself ;) the OJ is also one thing that never disappoints! They do a great job at keeping it fresh! Decent prices & good service make for the 5th star!
author: Karla E.

description:
I've been coming here regularly for over 2 1/2 years and due to recent service over the past few weeks, I am swearing off ever coming back. I'm sick of getting bagels with unripe tomatoes. I'm sick of getting bagels that are either burnt, or virtually untoasted. I'm sick of having to tell the employees what I want every single time even though I literally order the exact same thing every time I come in, and I've been here over a hundred times.

But above all, I'm sick of buying coffee and getting *a cup of hot water that vaguely tastes like coffee*, which is what their drip coffee has become over the past month or so. I took a sip this morning and decided I was not dealing with this BS again, I asked for it to be exchanged for an americano. I get an americano in BOILING WATER... are you kidding me? ...that is too hot for me to drink. I let it cool off while I'm at work, take a sip, and it's even more watery and flavorless than the drip.

I've been patronizing this place long enough, while leaving tips, and asking to switch the coffee this morning is literally the only hassle I've ever given them in over a hundred times coming here. I don't care how convenient its location is being a block away from work, and that they have both bagels and coffee, which is what keeps me alive in the morning. I'm just done. I've had it with this place. Never coming back.
author: Brendan R.

description:
Above average ... and a very decent cup of coffee in an upscale coffee shop.  Ordered one of the pastries with the cup.  I have no real complaints and I did like the pastry and food selection.  2 cups of coffee and 1 shared elephant ear pastry was a pretty good deal.   
I think the workers seemed pretty mellow and were happy to have caught them on a low key day like today.
author: Tito Y.

description: I haven't tried the coffe yet( I know, shocking) but I have had the pleasure in tasting the yogurt parfait and red velvet cupcakes. mmm mmm good. I simply adore the seating accommodations and the staff seem to enjoy their job, which is always refreshing. tah tah for now Cumaica.
author: Court S.

description:
Everything about this place is mediocre. 

The food, the service, the quality of ingredients in their pre-made snacks, the tea, and especially the coffee. No, especially the service. No, the coffee. Okay, it's all very lackluster. The coffee is bitter; I will ALWAYS walk the extra 3 blocks to either Ma'velous or Gaslamp to avoid the bitter burnt taste of their wannabe morning pick me up.
author: Jessica C.

description:
Best part about this place is the vegan, gluten free and 'clean' food options. Great healthy choices with no 'crap' additives, all natural ingredients - pasta salads, wraps, freshly squeezed juices, low fat yogurt parfaits... Just awesome. 
Had a latte and cappuccino from here - found both to be bitter and bold, needed to add sugar to smooth it out. 
Free wifi is nice.
author: Jenna M.

description: good place to go for cheap coffee and breakfast...all the girls working there are really nice and they make sure to get you your coffee or food fast as possible...
author: Loc N.

description: I go into Cumaica all the time and the staff is always extra friendly. Always making sure my hot chocolate is extra hot just how i like it! shout out to Roberto!
author: Molly L.

description: Quiet spot to get a lot of work done.  Don't have to fight over outlets. Music is not too loud and the food so far is great.  Would come back.
author: Art M.

description: I've been to a lot of coffee places and this places wins hands down with customer service and speed.  Let's face it I need my coffee stat before work. Most places make you wait. Here the staff move quickly and get my your coffee fast. Good prices. Good coffee, strong but not bitter. I highly recommend.
author: Timoteo K.

description:
This is my spot! It's the coffee shop down the street from the company I moved to SF for, so I have a natural place in my heart for Cumaica.

The obsession began the morning I got an espresso, plugged my headphones in, and chugged away at work for 3 hours. The active hum of the crowds, espresso machine, and adorable staff - combined with an airy layout (real trees inside!) - kept me engaged forever.

The espresso is among the best I've had in the city. Sightglass's doesn't even compare.

Please, please, please give me my free WiFi back.
author: Jeena C.

description:
Good bagels, good lattes, $5 minimum for credit cards. The girls behind the counter are always nice and very helpful. I love the small couches and tables by the door. I've never used the internet here since when I go is usually to just sit and read. 

The only thing is that the main door is always wide open and the area where this coffee shop is located is so windy, sometimes is hard to just sit there when you have all this cold wind blowing in. Oh well.
author: Ezekiel G.

description: I like this place, given the location. It's near my office and not super expensive. I've had decaf lattes there and banana bread. Both really good. The service is awesome!
author: Cassy R.

description: Really great coffee and friendly service! Their iced latte is delicious as is their  regular coffee. Pastries and sweets are good too. All around, great coffee. The closest thing to Blue Bottle I've found and coffee is very strong. Space is also bright and airy-I haven't worked here but seems like a good place to be productive.
author: Semuteh F.

description: Coffee was good, people were super friendly, service was quick, and they employ people with disabilities. Score!
author: Dina G.

description: The staff here is extremely friendly, and they have a family feel. Food is perfect for a small, light breakfast on the run. They play country music in the mornings sometimes. Their locally roasted coffee beans are also really good to take home. Nothing too fancy, but they're fast and friendly. This is my go-to!
author: Ben S.

description:
I'm sick of crap like Starbucks, seriously. I'm tired of all the "hipsters" and Wall Street-esque tools and inept people who like crappy, burnt coffee and espresso who think the green mermaid or her equally crappy counterparts are the be all, end all of caffeinated, non-carbonated beverages. I'll go to Starbucks when I want something sweet that doesn't actually taste like coffee (aka a frap or smthg similar), because it really doesn't require good coffee or espresso. 

Now, that's not to say Cumaica's perfect. They've messed up a couple of times I've been there. But generally, they're consistently awesome. My mochas and my coffee are always strong, perfectly roasted, and smooth. It's always exactly as I want it. It's the perfect, hot temperature, never luke warm, and always amazingly aromatic, with the flavor to match. 

I really enjoy the place. The ladies at this location in the morning are always friendly and quick, too. And they carry Sonoma Muffin Works breakfast burritos, which are awesome (I haven't had anything from Sonoma Muffin Works I didn't love, actually).

They may be a little further from my work, but they're worth the walk.
author: Jennifer V.

description: What an absolute gem. With two Starbucks, a Peet's, Ma'Velous et. all within the same block - this was my favorite. The spicy chai with an add shot will do you right. They are quick, acknowledge you fast, and make coffee well too. There's also quick grab things in case you need lunch/breakfast on the run.
author: Christina M.

description: I really like this cafe. The food and juice is really fresh (especially the OJ). The staff is super friendly.
author: E L.

description: Perfect cup for a morning commute. Very friendly staff and they make a decent iced latte
author: Peter G.

description: I ordered a vanilla latte and a pre made sandwich. Latte was excellent but the sandwich was dry. I thought I was eating a bread roll.
author: Omar O.

description:
Popped in here yesterday for a caffeinated beverage and some quick lunch. The chai latte that I got was phenomenal and just the way I like it - 5 stars for that.

As for the lunch options: when it states Deli on the window of a place, I kind of expect that they can build you up a sandwich or a wrap or whatever. Their "Deli" consisted of pre-made sandwiches in the likes of chicken with pesto on sourdough. They also had a variety of pre-made salad containers - however every single one of them contained pasta. So no leafy greens for me. Bummed out about the options, I grabbed a chicken on multi-seed bread with pesto and provolone. The sandwich was dry, forgettable and could have been made better by simply adding some slices of tomato and lettuce leaves as well as a little more pesto.  - 2 stars for the food options (my expectations would have been lower had there not been a "deli" sign out front).

Yes, the drink was better than the Starbucks chai latte, but I'd rather go to the chain that has a lot more options on food. At least at Starbucks I can get a meat/cheese platter or a juicy egg salad sandwich or even a salad. 

The space seemed nice, but we didn't stay there to eat. Next time I'm in this area I'd rather walk another block or two and see what else there is.
author: Anna R.

description:
Really nice coffee shop. I go down there about once a day in the afternoons during breaks at work. They make a good Frappe Chai and Matcha.

I saw a sign the other day that said Apple Cider. I was disappointed to find that they don't use real apple cider. It's some powdered crap that's really weak. They also charge you $2.25 for what costs them about 20 cents. I can make powdered Apple Cider anywhere for a lot cheaper then what I payed them for. If they had real Apple Cider they would get 5 stars.
author: Kelly B.

description: Don't come to this cafe! They only give you wifi password for 30mins and don't eve tell you when you are trying to buy the drink. It sucks!
author: Xiaofan L.

description: People behind the counter weren't rude, but also far from friendly. Food was all pre-made, cold, with no offer to warm it up. Kinda all just meh
author: Kale F.

description: This place has fixed exactly everything I previously had a gripe about: they accept credit cards without a minimum (on par with Starbucks) and they now churn-out consistent above-average non-over-sugared soy lattes.  To add to that: unlike the peets/Starbucks chains - they don't have a massive morning lines, probably because they have all those latin spitfires taking orders from those behind in queue.  Best of all, they don't pull one of those cheap maneuvers, like they do at Sightglass (the coffee snobbery around the corner that only serves one size latte), where they, like Cumanca, run your card in their iPad mounted on a swivel platform then turn it around for you to sign and have buttons where you choose from 3 tip options: 15, 20 and 25%, then stand there witnessing your actions. This place just runs your card, asks if you want a receipt, and doesn't try to witness a tip you give or make you feel guilty for not leaving one since: we all know that batista is not the same as a waiter.
author: Khash C.

description:
The Civic Center area and SOMA below it have always seemed like a coffee wasteland (except Sight Glass of course). And there are a couple Starbucks on Market..

Yesterday a shiny new Martha and Bros (a local chain) opened at 10th and Mission. Beautiful dark wood tables and seating, spacious airy ambiance. Not sure of their opening time but all other locations open by 7am, maybe earlier, on weekdays.

They're open weekends and they will have free wifi. It's worth cutting down a block from Market (or away from the Folsom St Fair) for a cup especially if you want great pastries or bagels with your fix.
author: Susie W.

description:
I need my small single shot mocha and Martha and her brothers does not disappoint.  I was getting the default double shot mocha for a bit until the jitters started to get a little annoying when I was trying to write and have a normal conversation with coworkers. Scary.  

Very cozy and roomy (is that a paradox?) with a grand view of Mission & 10th if you're into transient/hobo watching.
author: Irene C.

description: I went with my co-worker to buy a coffee and a morning star pastry. The cashier charged me for two morning stars, my coffee & my co-worker's cup of ice water.  I didn't mind that she charged me for my co-worker's morning star but she charged me a dollar for the ice water.  She didn't warn me that we had to pay for the ice water, especially since we've already bought something.  And their coffee has been watered down lately.  I'm not going back there anymore.  They just lost a good customer!
author: rose l.

description:
Meh. Not sure I get what the good reviews are about. They roast their own coffee, kudos to them. I cam here based on the reviews needing a place to work that was not my office for a change. As I sit here trying to focus, this is just not the place. 

First of all, prices are higher than other places, including, but not limited to Starbucks. This is fine, as long as they are serving a superior product. They are not. Slightly less burnt than Starbucks, but definitely more watered down. Strike one. 

Aside from that, all seats are very hard and uncomfortable wood. Makes it tough to work in this environment. Strike two. 

The two guys thinking that they are having an intellectual conversation very loudly, but really just repeating mindless nonsense and cackling loudly about it, well, they are annoying, but I understand that a business cannot necessarily control their clientele. 

However, on a very hot day in the city such as today, WHY IS THERE NO AC ON??? biggest offense and definitely strike three. I should leave at this point, but I have already committed, so I will probably just struggle through as much more as I can take and head out. Would definitely have been better off at Starbucks with very similar mediocre coffee, but at least I know for next time.
author: Miguel V.

description: Ok matcha latte...but -3 stars for brittle, dry and old cookies..almost broke a tooth
author: Megan C.

description: Charmless.  Second rate pastry.  The barista didn't know what she was doing.  Latte?  Like "Water for Coffee".
author: Robert L.

description:
Friendly staff & good prices. Not always open when you want them to be (close at 3pm on Sat & closed on Sun). It'd be nice if they had a salad option but what I had was good.

Coffee - whatever coffee of the day was. Tasty, well roasted.
Chicken with veggies & light dressing (can't remember complete combo) - light, filling with the pasta, a cold salad which hit the spot.
Vegan peanut butter energy bar - w/ cranberries. Absolutely delicious! I'd eat another in a heartbeat & for only $2/bar it's totally worth it. 

Thanks ScoutMob for allowing me to get all this for 1/2 off!
author: Marissa H.

description:
I tend to be in this neighborhood on weekday evenings, and it's a gigantic pain how hard it is to find somewhere to hang out before an appointment that is not cold or full of crazy, homeless drug addicts. Cumaica has always had lots of tables available and has clean and pleasant interior design. I have yet to be bothered by anybody, possibly because this is where the local cops get their joe.

The menu, service, and prices are typical of independent coffee shops in the general Starbucks/Peet's spectrum. Come here for the usual range of flavored lattes if you're already in the neighborhood. Don't go out of your way. Don't expect it to be a real cafe with a good lunch menu.

Their weekend hours suck!
author: Franzeska D.

description: This place is on my way to my bus stop, and every time I go, I always get that darn tomato mozzarella panini toasted to go.  It is SO DELICIOUS.  I've tried a few of their coffees, their iced coffee is my favorite.  Now that it's winter, I'll get a triple non-fat latte (normal latte has 2 shots, no matter what size - it's good, but 3 is what I need at 7am).  Can't recommend this place enough!
author: Emily H.

description:
Tiësto disappointed. Cumaica did not.

There is a lot to be said for doing what you're good at. Take Tiësto. He was once my favorite trance DJ. He changed to house/electro. Something all the young cool kids like. It's terrible. 

Waking up after his extremely disappointing Halloween show (perhaps my last), I needed caffeine to wake me up and help me get over my broken musical heart.

Fortunately Cumaica knows what they are good at. Coffee. Friendly service. Open and welcome space. 

And they aren't bad with turkey bagel sandwiches either.

Much better deal than the self proclaimed "greatest DJ of all time."

Tiësto could learn a thing or too from Cumaica.
author: Jason B.

description: I like it here but there's so many people that are loud. I"m not sure if it's the location or something. Windows are nice but you can't sit anywhere near the window unless you're wearing sunglasses.
author: Tiff W.

description:
Pretty good Chai. I don't really go to coffee shops so I don't really know if their prices are standard or not. But being the growing hipster that I am, I might come to a place like this to pretend working on something important on my laptop.

What is Cumaica?
author: Dorian T.

description:
I have been coming here off and on for about two months. Most of the time I used cash. Most recently, within days of visiting I noticed my debit card was compromised. Then again, within a few days of visiting, my credit card has fraudulent charges.

I noticed someone swipe my card the most recent time, ask for the card back and then quickly hunch over casually to do something with my card, away from view, while talking to someone else. I am concerned.
author: Jenny T.

description: Friendly baristas, good coffee, tasty food. Affordable. Can't really ask for much else.
author: Pablo A.

description: I would say, after investigating, that Cumaica has the best coffee in the neighborhood.  Their service is fast and friendly and the prices are below average.
author: Jennifer L.

description: Coffee/tea and foods are both okay. Great meeting place however due to the many seats and tables as opposed to Starbucks.
author: Lo Y.

description:
The Product: They roast their own coffee. The coffee they handed me is dark and smooth with a slightly bitter finish. It's good, but not very impressive - average. They do seem to have different blends, though, so be mindful of that when considering this review. If you're working nearby and need a cup, it's pretty cheap here:

12oz for $1.50
16oz for $1.75
20oz for $2.00

The Venue: If you've never been to the area, 10th and Mission isn't ghetto, but it does have a lot of the drunk, homeless, and mentally ill. During the day it's fine, but it's one of those areas you tell your kids to stay away from during later hours. Metered parking and downtown traffic makes for a crappy drive - take the bus. In terms of the actual establishment, they have one large table that seats six, ten tables that seat one-two, a couple of couches, and some desktop computers if you don't want to use their free wifi. Not really crowded and plenty of seats. Location aside, I like the interior a lot.

Overall: It's pretty out of the way for most people, even if the inside's a decent study spot. Coffee is just average - there is better in the area if you're a coffee snob like me.
author: Gun-Ik P.

description:
Caveat on the internet service: You only get two hours free (Which was fine for me on this particular day, but if you're a regular cafe warrior, this might be a problem).

I came here to work for a bit while waiting for repair work being done on my car in a nearby shop. I enjoyed my Chai Tea Latte, but their veggie pizza was undercooked and doughy, which I didn't like. Then again who would come for the food anyway? Internet service is fast, music is decent (standard alternative/indie rock fare). The decor leaves something to be desired. It's a little sad with the peeling windows, scratched up furniture and the floor is filthy.
author: Michelle L.
Russ O.

description: The lox bagel is excellent! I ate here on my way to a conference every day and it was super delicious!
author: Ryan W.

description:
I work on the same block as this place, so I figured it would be great and easy coming here for my morning coffees if I'm too lazy to cross the street over to Starbucks at Fox Plaza.

When this place first opened, I thought it was great. I enjoyed the mochas. I especially enjoyed the "Bring a friend and you both get free mochas" special that they had when they first opened.

Lately though, when my coworkers and I have come here for coffee, we've been disappointed. For instance, yesterday, one of my coworkers picked up drinks for 3 of us. He brought me back a latte and he brought my other coworker an orange juice while he had a tea. 

I took a sip of my coffee and looked at him questioningly, asked, "Ummm, what did you surprise me with?" He said he just got me a latte, and I said, "No! This is no latte... why is it salty?!"

Then when I said that, my coworker with the orange juice and I caught each other's eye and then remembered when 2 weeks ago, she and I came by for coffees but had to return her drink because her soy latte TASTED LIKE WARM FROTHY SALT WATER... it tasted even saltier than SOUP! When she returned it, she said that the person making her coffee did admit that their machine was acting funny. So why did they serve her?

Anyway, I took a break from work to go and return my drink the same way she did weeks earlier. When I went in, I told the cashier that my drink was salty even though it was a latte. She and one of the other workers just looked at each other with puzzled expressions. They looked extremely confused with each other, then looked back to me and asked, "Are you sure it's salty?" Well of course! I'm the one who was drinking it!

I told them to go ahead and taste it if they wanted to. Then all of a sudden, the two of them start speaking in Spanish to each other about why I was trying to get a new drink. No, I'm not trying to rip off the system - I just want a warm drink that doesn't taste like salt water! (By the way, in establishments such as this, I think it is EXTREMELY unprofessional for workers to be speaking to each other in a foreign language while conducting business. And I understood it anyway since I speak it a little bit myself.)

What made me even more mad was when they asked me what did I want them to do? As IF it wasn't obvious enough... I told them I wanted a new drink. I don't know why, but the woman who started making my new drink said, "If you want soy it's an extra 50 cents." For one, I never once mentioned wanting soy in my drink. And two, you guys are the ones who messed up my drink in the first place, and you should at least try to compensate for it! (You know, just a little something I learned from my hospitality classes when trying to make a customer's experience a little bit better.)

I ended up with a cappuccino that was meh. Oh well.

My coworker who got our drinks told me that he never orders coffee drinks from there because they always seem to taste a little off. Instead, he gets drinks or food that don't require someone making them. I should have listened to him.

I do have to admit though that their foccacias and their breakfast burritos DO taste very good. But for my hot drinks, I'm gonna stick to my Starbucks at Fox Plaza.
author: Melissa D.

description:
Your average coffee house. They offer a wide variety of foodstuffs as well (the burritos & paninis are decent), and while the staff are somewhat proficient, they're still working out the kinks of being relatively new.

For example, the price of my triple espresso on the rocks varied from $2.75 to $4.00 every time I visited, depending upon who was working the register. When I requested consistency, they settled on $3.75, which seemed steep to me. You can get the same drink @ Sage around the corner for $2.25, and @ Starbucks down the street for $2.30. Out of curiosity, I asked for the manager for a price breakdown and discovered they charge you for the size of cup, NOT the contents. Unfortunate.

I need my coffee every morning. Since the quality of coffee isn't necessarily superior to that of nearby competitors, I think I'll gonna pass on Martha & Bros for now.
author: Matthew H.

description:
When I first started listening to drum and base, I would usually use my iPod headphones. They're small, convenient and they get the job done. But every once in a while, my old roommate would lone me his koss over-ear cans, and it was only then that I could notice the suddleties of the music; they deep undertones, they powerful bass lines, the craft that went into making the product. It was then that I would begin to understand what there is to love about the music.

Cumaica, thanks for helping me understand what there is to love about a latte.
author: Sajid R.

description: My very first day at my new job I stumbled across this gem & discovered their bagel & lox sandwich.  The kicker was their addition of cucumber to the standard cream cheese, lox, & capers filling- PHENOMENAL.  I also indulged in their chai latte which was equally as tasty.  If you're looking for a non-chain coffee shop with excellent service/personable staff, venture off the beaten path to Mission Street.
author: Kirsten S.

description: I want to like this place since it's in my neighborhood, but the customer service is really poor.  The young lady who took my order today made absolutely no effort to be friendly - I have experienced this from other workers here before. If the service was better and the atmosphere a little bit improved (a good sized location with a lot of potential, but little personality), I'd make an effort to come by more often.
author: Jenni L.

description: Even when the lines are long, I need only wait a few moments. The drinks are delicious, and I regularly have their asiago bagel with lox and creme cheese, which I love.
author: Melody G.

description:
Coffee was good and employees were friendly, but the food was the same uninspired offerings you can find at any other average coffee shop in SF. You know, the bakery with stars on the signs? 

Average.
author: Luke W.

description: An unlikely gem in an otherwise barren section of soma - thanks scout mob for introducing me to another local coffee option. Great iced coffee ($2.25), delicious caprese panini ($5, pre-made, but they'll toast it for you), yummy baked goods selection ($2-3; apple bread pudding was huge and delish). Really nice staff, clean, open space with lots of natural light from their south and west facing floor to ceiling windows (no, I'm not the building's real estate agent). Fairly low traffic now (i.e. plenty of quiet, open tables), but I suspect it'll be busier once twitter moves in next door. Enjoy it in peace while you can!
author: Danielle M.

description:
Don't get me wrong and don't tell my barista, I still love my Peets coffee, but Martha's is really, really good coffee and they are a local chain, so you got to support the cause.

Even better the new spot at Mission and 10th is a sweet spot in a neighborhood that so needed good coffee.
author: G R.

description:
I'm thrilled to have another coffee place pop up on my block that isn't 'Starcraps'. I walked in this morning with a groggy smile and was greeted with the nicest "hellos" that you could get on a Monday morning at 8:30. Granted they were highly caffeinated no doubt, but the customer service was great. I ordered a unadulterated iced coffee so I could really taste the brew. I was pleasantly surprised! The first sip tasted like smokey, fresh roasted beans. It tasted fresh and that is more than I can say for Peet's and Starcraps. The berry scone I had was completely fresh too! This place rocks and I'm so thankful they're taking over the SOMA coffee scene with their fresh brew and upbeat, caffeinated attitudes. Thanks Martha and thanks to your brother too!
(looks like Martha Bros has changed their name.... but is the coffee the same? We'll see!)
author: FA B.

description: Everything about this place is mediocre. The food needs to be improved. The sandwiches use processed, cold pressed deli meat on subway-like bread. The pastries are just typical cookies and other overly sweet, giant items. The sun shines inside and the place is usually boiling hot. The coffee is nothing special. This should be a gourmet cafe!! There are a ton of new buildings and offices in this area. But instead, this is just a mediocre donut shop.
author: Laurence S.

description:
Nice little SOMA coffee shop.  Had coffee and an egg bagel.  The coffee was, well, coffee, not bad, but not Philz.  The egg bagel sandwich was surprisingly good.  The atmosphere inside is very relaxed with lots of space.  Definitely a place you could sit and read a book or chill out.

For the price, this place is totally worth it if you're within walking distance, but probably not somewhere I'd seek out if I had to take the muni over.
author: Jessica J.

description:
The good:  The workers seemed friendly.

The bad:  (1) Poor WiFi connection.  (2) A woman who most likely suffered from mental illness kept on disturbing the patrons (She kept yelling, "Is everything baked???  Is everything baked???), and the workers did nothing about it - this really ruined the experience..  

The conclusion:  I'll walk to Starbucks a block away next time...
author: Shin C.

description: 3.50 for cappuccino which is more of a latte. Tastes like they used nonfat milk without me asking for it, and burnt. Burned my tongue on it to add insult to injury. Bad coffee should not cost this much.
author: Ivan N.

description: I am here almost every morning for my wake-up coffee and I love it. I can't stand the franchise places and this ones a local place...all good. The ladies in the morning are awesome - friendly, polite and professional. The only downside is that nearly all of their  sandwiches have pesto in them. I know it's an easy way to add lots of flavor but pesto in the middle of the day is just overwhelming. I would suggest sandwiches with aioli or more mustard. More vegetarian options too - sans pesto. and.. how about grilled cheese?
author: Jan W.

description: Great to work from! Laid back, no corporate place like Starbucks or Peets. Nice
author: Dirk d.

description: Good coffee and great paninis.  The service has improved drastically over the past few months.
author: L T.

description: Cleanest coffee spot in a three block radius!! My only criticism would be the real sugar and syrup at the coffee counter,  maybe something fake would be ok? I would suffer through and keep my own sweetener at work for this place.
author: A C.

description: Great service, but coffee is quite poor, does not have flavor, its almost as if the hot water was poured over the beans too fast.  The self serve counter is a mess, heck it was 630 am and it was already quite messy.  I've never seen it orderly or clean before.  Last resort for coffee and I give them 3 stars for their customer service only.
author: Sharif R.

description: Meh, generic & channeling starbucks. I had a really unsatisfying breakfast burrito here. Coffe was fine.
author: Talia S.

description: Tables were sticky. dirty. Napkins tucked into chairs. Crew is nice and reasonably fast. But where to sit?  Wet coffee and crumbs on 7 tables.
author: Steve B.

description: Grand Opening. A coworker of mine told me that they just opened this week.  Since I work on the same block, I'm excited to get a new local coffee shop in the area.  It looks like there's only pastries & coffee this week, but they'll be having sandwiches in the near future. Today I had a small white mocha & an onion bagel with cream cheese.  I'll be coming here a lot in the future.
author: Stacey L.

description: They are so friendly here! And the panini's aren't bad! Got the fresh mozz caprese with pesto grilled up in their panini press, only $5, very delicious and fresh bread! The iced tea is also satisfying, they rotate flavors.
author: Cori W.

description: Nice selection of drinks and delicious treats. Staff was friendly and attentive. Higher prices than expected but quality seemed to match. Open airy seating but road noise can be excessive.
author: Ceedee P.

description: With so many fantastic one off coffee shops in San Francisco, I initially felt a little guilty walking into Cumaica, however its proximity to my work made it appealing on a particularly stressful morning when I rushed out of my house leaving my breakfast sitting on the counter.  Shockingly, in my search for a good West Coast bagel (Dante says "abandon hope all ye who enter here") Cumaica may actually be at the top of the list of tolerable.  The folks running the counter are always pleasant, and service is prompt.  When my lox bagel arrives, its actually hot, which immediately gives it a boost over many of its comrades.  Taking a bite, its well toasted, and topped with the appropriate combination and portion of lox, cream cheese, capers, and cucumber (though I sometimes go rogue and substitute tomato!)  The everything bagels don't pack the same flavor punch of their East Coast counterparts, but they certainly come closer than the flavorless, tough bagels I've tried elsewhere.  Overall, not too shabby - enough in fact, that I have made it my spot when I need to bust out a quick lunch.  Try it - you'll like it.
author: Virginia B.

description: Yea- coffee shop close to work!!!  Besides aweome HOT coffee and great mozarella sandwhiches (which they heat up for you in a sandwhich press) the staff here is really cool.  Everyone is super friendly and always ready to help you out!  Totally love this place~
author: Dangerous T.

description: I'm here every day, even twice a day.  Used to be Martha's, which is why I visited in the first place about 2 years ago.  They already know my coffee order, and they make breakfast for me when I just say I need breakfast.  They are kind and personable.  The cops, firemen, and construction workers all come here ... need I say more?!
author: Antonia R.

description: Yummy soy hot chocolate..  close to work, perfect temp, not overly sweet, cheaper than the others too.
author: Vicky P.

description: I really don't get why this place has any good reviews. the coffee is sub-par, wifi is non existent, the food disgusting and the service...it's anything but service. The staff are all completely rude and inept. I've spoken to the manager about a double charge on my ATM card from them...took him 2 weeks and then he insisted it wasn't their fault. it was$5! not alot but a double charge nonetheless. this place is really close to my work which is the only reason I've given it a second try, but after the shit service I received today; NEVER AGAIN!!! I ordered a cup of coffee, was charged (paid in cash), waited (nobody else in line)....waited (both women behind the counter chatting away to each other)....waited..at 10 minutes I asked "is there any coffee made", the semi-conscious   women behind the counter just gave me a vacant stare....finally a portly women behind her said "we're making it now"... I asked for a refund since I was needing to be at a meeting....then vacant eyes said "oh no it's done". she took a cup filled it with coffee- then poured it into the top of their giant coffee pot and repeated this twice. it was non brew'd/steeped coffee. perfectly disgusting, I left it on the counter and told em to keep it. I don't get why they are all so.....vapid & clueless. I do know that I will never go back there again....I'd rather give my $ to one of the 3 Starbucks that are all within wlaking distance to this place. which really is a shame, given the opportunity I'd much rather support a mom n pop, non-corporate place. not the case with Cumaica.
author: Ax L.

description: the coffee is always too hot for me, but i am a fan.  quality coffee and always seek to support a local business, although they do have several locations throughout SF.
author: Mauri L.

description: I'd forsake Peats and become a regular if I lived nearby.  Great dark roast coffee, wonderful pastries (wow chocolate dipped macaroons), and for $6-7/lb, beans are cheap!
author: Don N.

description: The coffee is no better than Starbucks and the prices seem steep.  However, the service here is awful.  They have at least 4 people working the counter and you either get ignored or passed off to another employee.  Very inefficient system.  Not worth the effort for basically a starbucks quality experience
author: Bitzz B.
